The objective of FNCE203 is to study the major decision-making areas of managerial finance and some selected topics in financial theory. The course reviews the theory and empirical evidence related to the investment and financing policies of the firm and attempts to develop decision-making ability in these areas. This course serves as a complement and supplement to FNCE 100. Some areas of financial management not covered in FNCE 100 are covered in FNCE 203. These may include leasing, mergers and acquisitions, corporate reorganizations, financial planning and working capital management, and some other selected topics. Other areas that are covered in FNCE 100 are covered more in depth and more rigorously in FNCE 203. These include investment decision making under uncertainty, cost of capital, capital structure, pricing of selected financial instruments and corporate liabilities, and dividend policy. The prerequisites are FNCE100, FNCE101, STAT101, and STAT102.

Overall, students found this course to be very informational, with many reviews explaining that the understanding that students gained about corporate finance was impressive. 

Professor Gormley taught this class, and a number of students praised his preparedness, citing his lectures as incredibly well thought out. One student explained that “he is probably the most dedicated professor I’ve had here [at Penn].” Many also “appreciate the well-organized structure of the course and the detailed slides” that were presented. 

Many students warned that the course involved a heavy workload, with multiple students explaining that the professor’s case studies took anywhere from 5 to 10 hours to complete per week. There were eight case studies throughout the semester, which although time consuming were informative, plus a midterm and a final exam.
